The death penalty process in Virginia is shrouded in layers of secrecy. We oppose executions, but as long as they're legal in our state, they should be carried out with full transparency.

Take Action Now to End Secrecy in the Death Penalty

The ACLU of Virginia opposes the death penalty but as long as it's legal in our state, every aspect of it should be transparent to the public. Sign our petition to Governor Ralph Northam and tell him to pull back the curtain on executions in the Commonwealth!

TAKE ACTION

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Several news media outlets recently filed a lawsuit against the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) to force it to allow legal witnesses observing executions on behalf of the public to view the entire process when the government kills someone.

This is important because it is the only opportunity for anyone other than the VDOC to see the person's condition – whether they've been mistreated, malnourished, drugged or even if it's the right person – prior to them being killed by the state. If reporters present can't see everything, they can't tell the rest of us what happened. The curtain obscuring their view needs to go.

There are other aspects of secrecy in the death penalty in Virginia that are just as objectionable. For one, state law allows the VDOC to work in secret with compounding pharmacies to make drugs used in lethal injections that otherwise are hard to get. VDOC also refuses to release its 18-page "Execution Manual" to anyone, including the person to be killed or their lawyer, without heavy redactions.

For two and a half years, we have called on Virginia governors to take down the curtain, release the full manual, and take action to let the public know where the state gets its deadly drugs. In light of the new lawsuit, we renew that call and ask you to please sign our petition telling Gov. Ralph Northam to follow the American Bar Association's Execution Transparency Resolution and make public all aspects of this process as long as it remains legal in Virginia.

Thanks for sticking with us!

Claire G. Gastanaga
Executive Director, ACLU of Virginia
